Key Arguments: The Bill imposes draconian controls on free speech.
It is inconsistent with Australia's international human rights obligations.
The Bill allows government and big tech to silence and censor speech beyond reasonable limits.
It gives the government power to silence religious and political speech.
The Bill's definitions of misinformation and disinformation are vague.
Government communications are exempt from the Bill, creating an asymmetry.
The Bill gives excessive power to unelected bureaucrats without transparency or accountability.
There is a lack of mechanisms to hold digital service providers accountable for excessive policing.
The Bill breaches privacy by compelling information from digital platforms.
The penalties for non-compliance are excessive and create a chilling effect on free speech.
Main Themes: Vague Definitions and Potential for Abuse
Notable Quotes: This Bill will impose some of the most draconian controls on free speech in the Western world.
The Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The Bill includes a vague and ideological definition of 'harm' which risks it being weaponised to shut down legitimate speech.
